Riot posts this video highlighting how Lee Sin is incredibly secure as a champion and... outright ignores the elephant in the room, instead marking it off as a "big play".

Lee Sin? Is not balanced. Lee Sin is possibly the single most poorly balanced champion over a course of several years, compared to all other champions who've suffered from similar issues (Riot's balance team underestimating mobility as a factor of strength), such as Talon or LeBlanc, who they've accordingly nerfed into a respectable position by deleting their one reliable form of crowd control in both cases.

This guy? For whatever reason, his ultimate repositions the target by more than he is even capable of repositioning himself, and as we should be well-aware of by now (Blitzcrank, Alistar) repositioning is the hardest form of crowd control.

So, what gives, Riot? Mind explaining what's going on with this guy, or if you plan on changing anything to help him along in the seasons to come? 
Thanks for taking the time to read my post expressing a sum of the community's concerns for this champion and why we weren't as impressed with this Big Plays clip as we have been with the others.

They left Lee alone for a long time because they didn't exactly know how to nerf him without killing him, but people started crying for Lee Sin nerfs real badly, then they made a massive list of patch notes to rework him, and the resulting public outcry was even greater, so they pulled the changes back and made several smaller changes to him accross several patches... And people are still complaining.

I agree that Lee Sin isn't exactly "the most balanced champion ever", but Riot has been trying hard to get the guy into a decent spot without gutting him, they are very aware of his problems and have been trying to fix him for a loooong time. If it was that easy, they would've done it already.

Lee sin uses 3 skills in this video... and is under half life.....
Also 3 people focused down a half life Irelia.

Half life 3 confirmed

so... Lee kicks a player away with a skill that can't miss then runs. His team comes in to save him and he's gets a spotlight?

QRW RUUUUUUNNNNNN!
"Outplayed!"

All this proves is that Lee Sin has ***VASTLY*** more tools and mobility at his disposal than he should. The player's fast reactions are praiseworthy to be sure, but seriously?  The amount of power that champion is allowed to have is just disgusting.
but the amount of skill it takes to fully utilize this mobility is insane. you can't just throw Lee Sin to some newbie and expect them to be anywhere near that good. therefore, not broken.

Oh no, I'm not implying they're unskilled, though I would ***heavily*** disagree the skill level required is "insane". People have been pretending he's like 3x harder than he is to justify his ridiculously overloaded kit since his release. Saying it doesn't make it so. 

He's still a ridiculously overpowered champion (he's been in the top 3 junglers, usually *the* top jungler, since his release years ago for a *reason*), but that's not to say people aren't skilled users of him. I just think the *overwhelming* majority of the work is done by the champ itself. He's got a disgusting amount of mobility and a disgusting amount of answers to any situation. A good Lee Sin ***never*** has to fight a battle he doesn't want to, and that's just plain bad. 

Again, the player's reaction speeds and quick thinking are definitely commendable, the fact that this "big play" is even possible is not, and is evidence of a distinct balance problem with Lee Sin. The player didn't bait around the Irelia, or manipulate cooldowns or damage in a meaningful way, he just did basic Lee Sin stuff as fast as he could and got way more results than he should have from it. 

A trend amongst the Lee Sin community: literally anything they do utilizing even the most basic part of his way overloaded, over-mobile kit is "outplaying" someone. You don't see Caitlyn's saying "outplayed" for landing their Qs, or Nasus saying "outplayed" for farming his Q. It's a unique trait of Lee Sin mains to think just ***using*** his skills is indicative of major skill, and, while it's annoying, it's not the fault of the players. It's the fault of a champion design with way, ***WAY*** more tools than almost any other champion, and flashy, fight-changing ones at that. Thats what I'm getting at. 

I in no way meant to imply the player lacked skill.
I believe the last paragraph applies to Master Yi users as well. :q

True enough, but I don't think anyone deludes themselves into believing that Master Yi does many "plays" (said from someone who has Yi in his top 5 most played champs). At most, you can Alpha-dodge stuff, or swap targets to better manage your resets in a fight. 

Meanwhile, the Lee Sin community be like "LOL I SHIT BETTER PLAYS THAN YOU PLEBS MY CHAMP SO HIGH SKILL" every time they manage to find their Q key twice.
Well if you'd like to talk crap about it, I guess you can pull the same thing off? If not, I guess you have no right to be dissing Riot's champion design choices or this guy's skill.

Yes, I can. And yes, I have, more than once. Lee Sin isn't nearly as hard as they pretend, and most people past a few games can do things like this guy did (provided they're decent players as a whole).  

He's not a hard champion, he's just a flashy one. He gets more bang for his buck out of EVERY one of his skills compared to most/all champions, and frankly isn't that hard to play.

So yeah, I'll talk crap about it. Like I said, the player reacted quickly which is cool and all, but nothing particularly special besides "He played Lee Sin the way only Lee Sin is OP enough to be played". No ill-will at all meant to the player. Just tired of Riot completely ignoring an OP champion and adding to the mentality of "LEE SIN SUCH OUTPLAY SO HARD MUH SKILLSHOT"

I'm pretty disappointed with this to be very honest. How is this classified as a big play? Anyone who understands Lee Sin would agree this is very basic. The only thing that was impressive I guess was the smite timing, but other than that this is a very obvious play that most Lee Sins should see instantly.

So, you, as Lee Sin, will instantly see, as the enemy team is invading your jungle and stealing your blue, that you can Q Irelia, ult her into your blue buff, take your Q onto Irelia who is now behind the blue buff and smite steal your own blue?
Technically, as Lee Sin, you wouldn't see anything. You would just sense that the enemy team is attacking your blue buff....

Riot, we're kinda getting sick of the juke plays with only Lee Sin and Katarina. The only other plays are supports setting up team fights, and sure that's great too, but can we see something different for once? How about that amazing 2v4 with jungle and mid lane? A global snipe to win the team fight? Anything but another juke, because we all get that they can do it because they were made to.
